Unlike components, where styles are expected to be contained, base styles are global, affecting the entire website. Here you will determine your fonts, colors, and default HTML element styles.

Quick Links

  • Typography updates
  • Color updates
  • Other base styles

Typography

The Typography page automatically pulls information regarding your fonts from your styles. This page is a quick way to view how your fonts will appear across various heading levels and when applied to paragraphs and lists. No additional setup is required.

Color

The Color page, like the Typography page, is also self-updating. However, it receives its information by reading your /scss/modules/_vars.scss file. Color variables found within the file will be displayed on the page.

There are four types of colors: brand, accent, utility, and neutral.

Type Description
Brand A website’s primary colors. For example, Pepsi’s brand colors are red, white, and blue. Any Sass variable beginning with $color-brand- will be added to this category.
Accent Colors for minor embellishments. Used when a brand color isn’t appropriate but some color treatment is still needed. Any Sass variable beginning with $color-accent- will be added to this category.
Utility Colors with specific meaning. For example, red is often associated with error messages, and green often represents a successful action. Any Sass variable beginning with $color-utility- will be added to this category.
Neutral Muted colors, usually shades of grey. Used for backgrounds or content separation. Any Sass variable beginning with $color-neutral- will be added to this category.

Variations on a color can also be created. These are displayed as smaller color tiles within a parent tile. To create a color variant, add another hyphen to the end of the color name followed by a name for the variant.

Example: A light version of the primary brand color may have a name like $color-brand-primary-light or $color-brand-primary-90

Other Base Style Pages

Other base styles can be displayed in the pattern library as well. By default, you will see pages for Buttons, Forms, and Tables. Unlike the Typography and Color pages, these are custom pages, allowing you full control over the HTML content. You can create more pages like them or remove them altogether.

For more information about creating and managing custom pages, see the Custom Pages section of this guide.
